div.p: The original transcription is not available.

To the local report no. 2767 of the political report no. 187 from April 8th 1940 about the Jewish law I would like to announce that the Ministries and all the central offices issued a whole lot of the internal decrees to get the Jewish law carried out in their area of competence and to get the Jews working as civil servants immediately eliminated from their positions. The list of names of such Jews stripped of their positions was given to print. As an interesting fact I would like to also state, that also Jews who held their official functions at the withdrawn areas of Bessarabia and northern Bukovina were a part of this list. This brought a smile to the faces of critical people; however its purpose was to prevent these Jews – clerks from the areas of Bessarabia and northern Bukovina – from getting employed as civil servants back in Romania. The critical voices from the local diplomatic corps can be also heard, since according to them an issue with the Jews as civil servants was an easy one to solve because there were not many of them and none at the leading positions.

In practice, the carrying out of the Jewish law faces some issues as well, coming from standards governing this issue. The legal decrees about the National party state that only a member of the Party can become a member of an executive board and vice-versa [...] the law states that a Jew cannot become a member of the National party at all.

This law, thus, does not give Jews a chance to remain members of the executive boards of companies. Nevertheless, the Jewish law (see the quoted report) prevents only the Jews of the first and the third category to become members of executive boards and does not create any obstacles for the Jews of the second category. From all of that a practical question arises in the companies, that is which of the two legal decrees is valid. It is only natural that the Jews are trying to hold on to the more convenient Jewish law with all the means possible, since based on the information I got it is not at all easy for Jews to prove their right to be in the second category, because the competent offices are making operative steps in this issue and are supposedly dismissing also those proofs which satisfy the formal requirements.

I am not sure whether I am mistaken, but it seems that the differences between the legal decrees are not coincidental. It is hard to imagine such frivolousness, especially when it comes to such an important issue for Romanian economic life. Thus, it can be assumed that it is something intended for great deal of elasticity in this issue.

The inconsistency in the execution of the decrees can be seen also within the army, where each of the divisions applies the decrees individually. I was informed about cases where regiments simply demobilized a Jewish rank and sent it home. The other regiment, however, sent a Jewish rank

home in uniforms and told them to come back in their plain clothes to then decide their fate. Finally the third regiment demobilized its Jewish rank immediately, however they were told to come back every morning and every afternoon in their plain clothes to ask about any work that comes up. Similar inconsistent solutions are possible when it comes to the local administrative customs.

The overall picture one gets from these individual events is that when it comes to the solution of the Jewish problem, the steps taken are going to depend on the given situation and will be opportunistic enough to bring the most for Romania and Romanian population. It is convenient exactly for these opportunistic possibilities that the basic decrees are so different and that, even more than with any other laws, in this case everything will depend on how the steps are being executed and on the administrative practice.
Made in 6 copies, 4 of them for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, 1 copy for the army attaché and 1 copy to be stored within the records.
